review: When I first heard you could 'beam' your favorite media (Netflix, Hulu, Amazon movies, etc...) from your computer, I thought "Now that's what I want!"  I actually own a smart TV so I'm able to get most of those services on my TV anyway, however, this little gem lets me stream much more than my TV can.  (It especially comes in handy when there are certain shows you can't stream because of Hulu's guidelines.)The only "complaint" I have is that sometimes my laptop and TV/Chromecast don't talk to each other or sound is missing.  I've had to re-install software for the first issue and re-beam the Internet page for the second issue.Overall I like this cool device and would recommend it to others.
author: Mom of 1/Teacher of Many "One Review At A Time"

review: This is a great little device that's even greater if you know how to expand on its capabilities.  Two things I highly recommend to do this are XBMCast and the Avia app.  Google the first, the latter is in the Play Store.  With these two things (total one time cost about 8 dollars), the content available to stream from your Android phone or table is wide open utilizing the '1channel' addon in XBMC.  There's also a lot of talk on the town in the past week of a roll out for Google Play Services that will add the function to 'cast screen' to certain tablets and phones.  A partial list slated for the first rollout includes the Galaxy line of phones and the Nexus 7 2013 and the Nexus 10.1.  When this talk becomes reality, this will absolutely be the best value in streaming devices on the market, hands down.  It already is if you know how to open up its potential.
